Goodness-of-fit tests for complete spatial randomness based on Minkowski functionals of binary images

Bruno Ebner, Norbert Henze, Michael A. Klatt
Institute of Stochastics, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT),
Englerstr. 2, D-76131 Karlsruhe, Germany
and
Klaus Mecke
Institute of Theoretical Physics 1, University Erlangen-NÃ¼rnberg,
Staudtstr. 7, D-91058 Erlangen, Germany The author gratefully acknowledges funding by the German Research Foundation (DFG) via the Grants No. HU1874/3-2 and No. LA965/6-2 awarded as part of the DFG-Forschergruppe FOR 1548 â€œGeometry and Physics of Spatial Random Systemsâ€.
Abstract

We propose a class of goodness-of-fit tests for complete spatial randomness (CSR). In contrast to standard tests, our procedure utilizes a transformation of the data to a binary image, which is then characterized by geometric functionals. Under a suitable limiting regime, we derive the asymptotic distribution of the test statistics under the null hypothesis and almost sure limits under certain alternatives. The new tests are computationally efficient, and simulations show that they are strong competitors to other tests of CSR. The tests are applied to a real data set in gamma-ray astronomy, and immediate extensions are presented to encourage further work.


Keywords: Poisson point process, geometric functionals, nonparametric methods, thresholding procedure, astroparticle physics

1 Introduction

The statistical analysis of spatial point pattern data in a given study area Sğ‘†S (often called the observation window) is a classical task in many applications, including biostatistics (e.g. structure analysis, Dazzo etÂ al., (2015)), astronomy (e.g. detection of gamma-ray sources, GÃ¶ring etÂ al., (2013)), military (e.g. mine field detection, Lake and Keenan, (1995)) and medicine (e.g. cluster detection in leukemia incidence, Wheeler, (2007)). A main objective is to characterize possible departures from so-called complete spatial randomness (CSR) of point patterns, which characterizes the absence of structure in data. CSR models the non-occurrence of dependence of point events within a given study area Sğ‘†S, and it is synonymous with a homogeneous spatial Poisson point process (PPP). For an introduction to the concept of CSR we refer to Cressie, (1993), Section 8.4, and Okabe etÂ al., (1992), Chapter 8. To be precise, we model the observed data by

ğ’«Î»:={X1,â€¦,XNÎ»},assignsubscriptğ’«ğœ†subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ‘ğœ†{\cal P}_{\lambda}:=\{X_{1},\ldots,X_{N_{\lambda}}\},

where Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0, (Xj)jâ‰¥1subscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘—ğ‘—1(X_{j})_{j\geq 1} is a sequence of independent identically distributed random vectors taking values in Sğ‘†S, and NÎ»subscriptğ‘ğœ†N_{\lambda} is a nonnegative integer-valued random variable, independent of (Xj)jâ‰¥1subscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘—ğ‘—1(X_{j})_{j\geq 1}, with a distribution that depends on some parameter Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0. All random elements are defined on the same probability space (Î©,ğ’œ,â„™)Î©ğ’œâ„™(\Omega,{\cal A},\mathbb{P}). For ğ’«Î»subscriptğ’«ğœ†{\cal P}_{\lambda} to be CSR the (Xj)jâ‰¥1subscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘—ğ‘—1(X_{j})_{j\geq 1} are uniformly distributed on Sğ‘†S, and NÎ»subscriptğ‘ğœ†N_{\lambda} has a Poisson distribution with expectation Î»ğœ†\lambda. The assumption of CSR will be called the null hypothesis H0subscriptğ»0H_{0}, and our aim is to test H0subscriptğ»0H_{0} against general alternatives.

The problem has been considered in the literature, for a good overview of the existing methods, see e.g. Cressie, (1993); Illian etÂ al., (2008); MÃ¸ller and Waagepetersen, (2003). Different approaches to construct a test of CSR include quadrat counts, distance methods (e.g. nearest neighbor and empty spaces), second-order characteristics like the Kğ¾K- or the Lğ¿L-function, or other measures of dependence. The related problem of testing for uniformity of point patterns with a fixed number of points (i.e. if â„™â€‹(NÎ»=n)=1â„™subscriptğ‘ğœ†ğ‘›1\mathbb{P}(N_{\lambda}=n)=1 for some nğ‘›n) has been extensively investigated in the univariate case (see Marhuenda etÂ al., (2005) for a survey), but also in the multivariate setting, see Berrendero etÂ al., (2012, 2006); Ebner etÂ al., (2016); Justel etÂ al., (1997); Liang etÂ al., (2001); Tenreiro, (2007).

Our novel idea to test for CSR is to convert the point data within the observation window Sğ‘†S into a binary image, and then to evaluate this random image by means of the so-called Minkowski functionals from integral geometry, see Schneider and Weil, (2008). Such functionals encompass standard geometric parameters, such as volume, (surface) area, perimeter, and the Euler characteristic, which are robust and efficient shape descriptors that have already been successfully applied to a variety of applications, see SchrÃ¶der-Turk etÂ al., (2011); Klatt, (2016) and the references therein. These data driven and hence random functionals are examined under the assumption of an homogeneous PPP. We determine the mean values and their variance-covariance structure, which opens the ground for different test statistics. Moreover, we analyze an experimental data set by the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope, see Acero etÂ al., (2015). The Fermi sky map includes features whose physical causes are still unknown. New statistical methods could help to clarify some of these open questions.

The paper is organized as follows. In the next section we explain the transition of the data to a binary image using a binning and a threshold procedure. Section 3 deals with calculating the Minkowski functionals in an efficient way, while Section 4 provides the mean values and the variance structure under the hypothesis. In Section 5 we propose different test statistics and derive their H0subscriptğ»0H_{0}-asymptotics under some suitable limiting regime. The complete covariance structure between the functionals as well as statistics using more than one functional are presented in Section 6. Section 7 is devoted to questions of the behaviour of the tests under an inhomogeneous Poisson Process alternative. In Section 8 and Section 9, simulation results as well as a data example illustrate the efficiency of the presented methods. We finally state possible extensions and open problems in Section 10.

3 Minkowski Functionals and Local Dependency

The main idea underlying the new tests of CSR is to evaluate the resulting binary image by means of geometric functionals. In the bivariate case, there are three Minkowski functionals, namely the area, the perimeter, and the Euler characteristic. Knowledge of the values of these functionals does not characterize the binary image. Nevertheless, Hadwigerâ€™s characterization theorem states that every functional acting on nonempty compact convex subsets of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}, dâˆˆâ„•ğ‘‘â„•d\in\mathbb{N}, that is additive, continuous and invariant under rigid motions can be written as a linear combination of the Minkowski functionals, for details see Schneider and Weil, (2008), p. 628.

A natural question is: Given a mÃ—mğ‘šğ‘šm\times m binary image with white border, how can these functionals be computed in an efficient way? Obviously, we can calculate the area by simply counting the black cells, but the answer for the other functionals is more involved. However, results from image analysis allow to establish a look-up table like Table 1 (even in higher dimensions), see Gray, (1971); Mantz etÂ al., (2008); Mecke, K. and Stoyan, D. , 2000 (Eds.) for early versions in two dimensions and Kong and Rosenfeld, (1989) for a survey.

Here, we move a small (2Ã—2)22(2\times 2)-window over the whole digital image (from top left to bottom right) and sum up the values given in the table according to the observed configuration. A basic feature of the structure underlying the look-up table is that each cell can only have an effect on the 8 neighboring cells, which implies a local dependency structure. Given a random digital image Zğ‘Z, we thus define

4 Mean and Variance under H0subscriptğ»0H_{0}

To establish a test statistic for CSR we need some characteristics like the mean, the variance and the covariance of the Minkowski functionals under the hypothesis H0subscriptğ»0H_{0}. In case of CSR the random variable Zi,jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—Z_{i,j} follows the binomial distribution Binâ€‹(1,pc)Bin1subscriptğ‘ğ‘\mbox{Bin}(1,p_{c}) where pc=â„™â€‹(Zi,j=1)=â„™â€‹(Yi,jâ‰¥c)subscriptğ‘ğ‘â„™subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—1â„™subscriptğ‘Œğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘p_{c}=\mathbb{P}(Z_{i,j}=1)=\mathbb{P}(Y_{i,j}\geq c), depends on the underlying known intensity Î»ğœ†\lambda of ğ’«Î»subscriptğ’«ğœ†{\cal P}_{\lambda} and the threshold cğ‘c. Clearly, if the parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda is unknown, we will have to estimate it with a good estimator. The natural way to estimate the intensity of a stationary planar Poisson process is to count the number of points falling into an observation window, and to divide this number by the area of the window which, in our case, is one. For more information on estimation techniques see for instance Gaetan and Guyon, (2010), section 5.5.2.1, or for newer developments Coeurjolly, (2017) and the references therein. 8 Simulations

In this section we compare the finite-sample power of the test based on a single Minkowski functional, i.e. Tjsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘—T_{j}, jâˆˆ{A,P,Ï‡}ğ‘—ğ´ğ‘ƒğœ’j\in\{A,P,\chi\}, as well as the tests based on Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} and T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c} that make use of all three functionals, with the power of several competitors. All simulations are performed using the statistical computing environment R, see CoreÂ Team, (2016). Notice that, strictly speaking, the new procedures form a two-parametric class of tests, depending on the threshold parameter cğ‘c, the mean number (under H0subscriptğ»0H_{0}) of points in each bin Îºğœ…\kappa and the number m2superscriptğ‘š2m^{2} of bins. The latter parameter is chosen to fulfill the limiting regime (14), and throughout this section we fix m:=mâ€‹(Î»,Îº)=âŒŠÎ»/ÎºâŒ‹assignğ‘šğ‘šğœ†ğœ…ğœ†ğœ…m:=m(\lambda,\kappa)=\scriptstyle\left\lfloor\sqrt{\lambda/\kappa}\right\rfloor, where âŒŠâ‹…âŒ‹â‹…\lfloor\cdot\rfloor is the floor function. Observe that no other choice of mğ‘šm has been considered, so that one might find combinations of m,cğ‘šğ‘m,c and Îºğœ…\kappa that result in a better power performance. The intensity Î»ğœ†\lambda of the simulated processes has to be estimated in a prior independent experiment and is therefore considered to be known. In each scenario we consider the intensities Î»âˆˆ{50,100,200,500}ğœ†50100200500\lambda\in\{50,100,200,500\}, and the nominal level of significance is set to 0.050.050.05. Empirical critical values under H0subscriptğ»0H_{0} for Tjsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘—T_{j}, jâˆˆ{A,P,Ï‡}ğ‘—ğ´ğ‘ƒğœ’j\in\{A,P,\chi\}, Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} and T~csubscript~ğ‘‡ğ‘\widetilde{T}_{c} have been simulated with 100â€‹000100000100~{}000 replications (see Tables 2 and 3), and each entry in Tables 4 and 5 referring to the power of the tests is based on 10â€‹0001000010~{}000 replications.

Notice that the 95%percent9595\% quantile of Ï‡12subscriptsuperscriptğœ’21\chi^{2}_{1} is 3.84, and that of Ï‡32subscriptsuperscriptğœ’23\chi^{2}_{3} is 7.81. The parameter mğ‘šm is chosen in such a way that, under H0subscriptğ»0H_{0}, the average number of points that fall into one bin is one. Consequently, the fluctuation of the critical values for c=5ğ‘5c=5 may result from a too small number of black bins.

As competitors to the new tests we considered the following procedures, which are all standard methods included in the package spatstat. We chose these procedures to have representatives of the different approaches, namely quadrat counts, distance methods, and methods based on the Kğ¾K- or the Lğ¿L-function.

  • (i)

    For the quadrat count Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}-test, see Baddeley etÂ al., (2015), one divides the observation window into disjoint squares B1,â€¦,Bksubscriptğµ1â€¦subscriptğµğ‘˜B_{1},\ldots,B_{k} with equal area 1/k1ğ‘˜1/k and counts the number of points U1,â€¦,Uksubscriptğ‘ˆ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘˜U_{1},\ldots,U_{k} in each square. Under H0subscriptğ»0H_{0} the Ujsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘—U_{j} are independent Poisson random variables with expected value Î»/kğœ†ğ‘˜\lambda/k. Given the total number of points NÎ»=âˆ‘j=1kUjsubscriptğ‘ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘—N_{\lambda}=\sum_{j=1}^{k}U_{j} the expected count in square Bjsubscriptğµğ‘—B_{j} is NÎ»/ksubscriptğ‘ğœ†ğ‘˜N_{\lambda}/k. The test statistic is then (see Baddeley etÂ al., (2015), p. 165, display (6.5))

    Q=âˆ‘j=1k(Ujâˆ’NÎ»/k)2NÎ»/k.ğ‘„superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğœ†ğ‘˜2subscriptğ‘ğœ†ğ‘˜Q=\sum_{j=1}^{k}\frac{(U_{j}-N_{\lambda}/k)^{2}}{N_{\lambda}/k}.

    Under the null hypothesis, the limit law of Qğ‘„Q is a Ï‡kâˆ’12subscriptsuperscriptğœ’2ğ‘˜1\chi^{2}_{k-1} distribution. Notice that one should choose kğ‘˜k in order to obtain expected counts greater than 5 in each square. Otherwise the approximation of the critical values is too far away from the theoretical quantiles. Hence we chose k:=âŒŠÎ»4âŒ‹assignğ‘˜4ğœ†\sqrt{k}:=\lfloor\sqrt[4]{\lambda}\rfloor to guarantee sufficiently many points in each square.

  • (ii)

    Hopkins and Skellam (see Hopkins, (1954); Skellam, (1954) and, for more details, Baddeley etÂ al., (2015), p. 259) proposed a test based on the combination of nearest neighbor distances and empty space distances. Consider a subsample of size nğ‘›n of the data and compute the nearest neighbor distances Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i}, i=1,â€¦,nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i=1,\ldots,n, and the empty-space distances Ejsubscriptğ¸ğ‘—E_{j}, j=1,â€¦,nğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘›j=1,\ldots,n for an equal number nğ‘›n of uniformly sampled spatial locations. Then the Hopkins-Skellam index is given by

    H=âˆ‘i=1nDiâˆ‘j=1nEj.ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›subscriptğ¸ğ‘—H=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}D_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}E_{j}}.

    Under the null hypothesis Hğ»H is distributed according to an F2â€‹n,2â€‹nsubscriptğ¹2ğ‘›2ğ‘›F_{2n,2n}-distribution. As remarked in Byth and Ripley, (1980) one should choose nâ‰¤NÎ»/10ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğœ†10n\leq N_{\lambda}/10 since the distributional theory is only known for a sparsely sampled homogeneous Poisson process, see Cressie, (1993), section 8.2.5, for details.

  • (iii)

    The Diggle-Cressie-Loosmore-Ford test (see Loosmore and Ford, (2006) and Baddeley etÂ al., (2015), section 10.7.4) computes a CramÃ©r-von Mises type test statistic

    D=âˆ«0R(L^â€‹(r)âˆ’Lâ€‹(r))2â€‹dâ€‹r.ğ·superscriptsubscript0ğ‘…superscript^ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ¿ğ‘Ÿ2dğ‘ŸD=\int_{0}^{R}(\widehat{L}(r)-L(r))^{2}\mbox{d}r.

    Here, Lâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¿â‹…L(\cdot) is the theoretical Lğ¿L-function of a homogeneous Poisson point process, L^â€‹(â‹…)^ğ¿â‹…\widehat{L}(\cdot) is an estimator of Lâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¿â‹…L(\cdot), and Rğ‘…R is a chosen upper limit on the range of distances of interest. A Monte Carlo type test, see Baddeley etÂ al., (2015), section 10.6, is then applied to Dğ·D to obtain a suitable rejection region.

For the simulation of alternative point processes we used the methods included in the R-package spatstat, as described in Baddeley etÂ al., (2015). In view of the results in Section 7 we chose an inhomogeneous Poisson point process with intensity measure Î»â€‹fâ€‹(x,y)â€‹dâ€‹(x,y)ğœ†ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦dğ‘¥ğ‘¦\lambda f(x,y)\textrm{d}(x,y), where f:[0,1]2â†’[0,âˆ):ğ‘“â†’superscript0120f:[0,1]^{2}\rightarrow[0,\infty) is a bounded continuous function with âˆ«[0,1]2fâ€‹(x,y)â€‹dâ€‹(x,y)=1subscriptsuperscript012ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦dğ‘¥ğ‘¦1\int_{[0,1]^{2}}f(x,y)\textrm{d}(x,y)=1. We also considered a further alternative point process, namely the Baddeley-Silverman cell process Bâ€‹Sâ€‹Pğµğ‘†ğ‘ƒBSP, as proposed in Baddeley and Silverman, (1984). This process is designed to have the same second-order properties as an homogeneous PPP so that it cannot be detected by Kğ¾K- or Lğ¿L-function methods. Itâ€™s the standard counterexample to the claim that these functions completely characterize the point pattern. The Bâ€‹Sâ€‹Pğµğ‘†ğ‘ƒBSP is generated by dividing the observation window into equally spaced quadrats in which either 0,1010,1 or 101010 points are independently uniformly scattered with probabilities 1/10,8/9110891/10,8/9 and 1/901901/90 respectively.

Due to ongoing interest in the detection of clusters in point patterns we considered the special case of a Neyman-Scott cluster process (for details see Cressie, (1993), p. 662), namely the MatÃ©rn cluster process Mâ€‹Câ€‹Pğ‘€ğ¶ğ‘ƒMCP, see Baddeley etÂ al., (2015), p. 139. In this model one first simulates a homogeneous PPP as parent points with fixed intensity Î»~~ğœ†\widetilde{\lambda}. In a second step, one generates a Poisson random number N~~ğ‘\widetilde{N} of independently uniformly distributed points in a disc of radius rğ‘Ÿr center around each parent point. Discarding the parent process yields the Mâ€‹Câ€‹Pğ‘€ğ¶ğ‘ƒMCP. We chose Î»~:=Î»/m,r=0.2formulae-sequenceassign~ğœ†ğœ†ğ‘šğ‘Ÿ0.2\widetilde{\lambda}:=\lambda/m,r=0.2 and set the parameter of the Poisson distribution of N~~ğ‘\widetilde{N} to m=âŒŠÎ»/ÎºâŒ‹ğ‘šğœ†ğœ…m=\scriptstyle\left\lfloor\sqrt{\lambda/\kappa}\right\rfloor.

Table 4 and Table 5 show the percentages (out of 10Â 000 replications) of rejections of H0subscriptğ»0H_{0} rounded to the nearest integer. In both tables, it is obvious that Tjsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘—T_{j}, jâˆˆ{A,P,Ï‡}ğ‘—ğ´ğ‘ƒğœ’j\in\{A,P,\chi\}, as well as Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} depend crucially on the choice of the threshold parameter cğ‘c. The difference between Table 4 and Table 5 is the choice of Îºğœ…\kappa, which is controlled by the number m2superscriptğ‘š2m^{2} of bins considered, and the simulation results clearly show the impact of a proper choice of cğ‘c and mğ‘šm. Fixing Îº=1ğœ…1\kappa=1 as in Table 4 a natural choice of the threshold parameter is c=1ğ‘1c=1, for which T1subscriptğ‘‡1T_{1} gives the best overall performance of the new methods and competes with the compared tests. In case of the BSP it outperforms the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2}-quadrat-count-test as well as the Diggle-Cressie-Loosmore-Ford-test. Table 5 provides more insight into the power of the new tests and the dependence on the parameters. Since Îºğœ…\kappa is the mean number of points falling into a single bin, one would expect the best performance for Îº=cğœ…ğ‘\kappa=c. Throughout the table, this assumption does not seem to hold. A slightly lower threshold parameter than Îºğœ…\kappa results in higher power of the tests. The power of the testing procedure that combines more than one Minkowski functional outperforms overall the procedures based on a single functional. Notice that the presented simulation results are based on a naive choice of the parameters, so there is hope to find better performing tests by optimizing the choice of Îºğœ…\kappa and cğ‘c, preferably in a data driven way.

9 Data analysis of gamma-ray astronomy

As an exemplary application, we analyze experimental observations from astroparticle physics, the gamma-ray sky map of the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope. This space observatory explores extreme astrophysical phenomena, namely high-energetic radiation from both galactic and extragalactic sources. These sources may be fast rotating neutron stars or hot gas moving nearly at the speed of light. The satellite was launched in 2008 and detects the gamma-rays from a low Earth orbit. The energies of the singly detected photons range from 20â€‰MeV to 300â€‰GeV; for comparison, a photon with a visible wavelength has energies below 3â€‰eV.

Here we analyze a sky-map of gamma-rays observed by the so-called Large Area Telescope (LAT)Â Atwood etÂ al., (2009). The directions of the incoming photons form a point pattern on the hemisphere. If the observation window is restricted to a small field of view, the curved space can be well approximated by a rectangular observation window in the Euclidean plane. If necessary, the analysis could easily be adapted from the plane to the sphere.

FigureÂ 3 shows a binned sky map, that is, the gray values represent the numbers of events detected within each bin. We here analyze a data set of 106superscript10610^{6} events (which were collected within about two months). The positions in the sky are given in galactic coordinates, that is, the galactic latitude BğµB and the galactic longitude Lğ¿L. The supermassive black hole in the center of our galaxy is at L=0ğ¿0L=0 and B=0ğµ0B=0. Above and below the black hole, there is an unresolved phenomenon, the so-called Fermi-Bubbles, as can be seen in Fig.Â 3. Its origin is still unknown, but it might be the result of a more active period of the supermassive black hole in the center of our galaxy, see Bordoloi etÂ al., (2017).

The null hypothesis is well-defined for any choice of the bin width, because the Poisson point process does not assume an intrinsic length. However, for the application to real data, a reasonable choice of the bin width in accordance with the resolution of the detector improves the sensitivity of the analysis. A too coarse graining can hide distinct geometrical features of sources within a single pixel. If the mesh is too fine compared to the point spread function, the black and white image can easily be dominated by the random scattering of the signals.

The resolution of the LAT depends strongly on the energies of the photons. It resolves the direction of the photons within a few degrees for 1â€‰MeV gamma-rays but with a resolution of about 0.2 degrees for energies above 2 GeV, see Acero etÂ al., (2015). The energy of the events analyzed here ranges from 1â€‰GeV to 1â€‰TeV. Accordingly, we choose a bin width of about 0.2 degrees or larger.

There are four contributions of the events detected by the LAT:

  1. a)

    strong galactic point sources, like active galaxies of the blazar class or pulsarsÂ Acero etÂ al., (2015),

  2. b)

    diffuse radiation from galactic gas clouds, that is produced by collisions of high energetic protons and particles in the gas clouds,

  3. c)

    an isotropic diffuse background from extragalactic sources, that cannot be resolved as single sources, but adds up to a homogeneous background, and

  4. d)

    an isotropic background of high-energetic protons. A small fraction of the protons in the cosmic radiation are incorrectly but unavoidably classified as gamma-rays. They arrive homogeneously from all directions after a diffusion in the galactic magnetic fields.

From a statistical point of view, these four contributions can be interpreted as:

  1. a)

    a strongly clustering (MatÃ©rn-type) point process,

  2. b)

    an inhomogeneous Poisson point process,

  3. c)

    and d) a homogeneous Poisson point process.

Here we analyze field of views that contain point sources within a homogeneous background as well as inhomogeneous diffusive radiation from the galactic disc, see Fig.Â 4. The first data set (upper left picture in Figure 4) contains 1041 point events. We chose as parameters Î»=1041ğœ†1041\lambda=1041 and m=18ğ‘š18m=18, which results in Îºâ‰ˆ3.213ğœ…3.213\kappa\approx 3.213. The second data set (upper middle picture in Figure 4) contains 1339 point events (Î»=1339ğœ†1339\lambda=1339, m=21ğ‘š21m=21 and Îºâ‰ˆ3.036ğœ…3.036\kappa\approx 3.036) and the third data set (upper right picture in Figure 4) exhibits 3193 point events (Î»=3193ğœ†3193\lambda=3193, m=32ğ‘š32m=32 and Îºâ‰ˆ3.118ğœ…3.118\kappa\approx 3.118). For all three analysis the thresholding parameter cğ‘c was fixed to 2 in accordance with the insight gained in section 8. The third data set is a region in the northern Fermi bubble with diffuse radiation from gas clouds, which causes a global gradient in the point pattern, and a point source, which is marked by the diamond symbol (â‹„â‹„\diamond). The latter is listed in the LAT 4-year Catalog as the source J1625.1â€”0021Â Acero etÂ al., (2015), which is likely to be a millisecond pulsar, e.g., seeÂ Dai etÂ al., (2016). For computing the pğ‘p-values in Table 6 we used the asymptotic Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2} distribution with 1 and 3, degrees of freedom, respectively.

Table 6 shows that Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{c} rejects the hypothesis of CSR for all 3 data sets, while TPsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ƒT_{P}, TÏ‡subscriptğ‘‡ğœ’T_{\chi} and Hğ»H clearly fail to detect the alternative in data set 1 even for a larger level Î±ğ›¼\alpha like 0.10.10.1. Data set 2 indicates the gain of power by considering the combination of 3 functionals, compared to the single functional. For data set 3 all tests, except TÏ‡subscriptğ‘‡ğœ’T_{\chi}, detect the inhomogeneous radiation in the region of the Fermi bubble. For reference we included the pğ‘p-values of the Hopkins and Skellam test. The quadrat count and Diggle-Cressie-Loosmore-Ford tests reject the null hypothesis, but since their power depend on parameters and on the number of Monte Carlo replications the pğ‘p-values are omitted since the comparability is questionable.

To detect point sources, the diffuse background radiation is estimated based on maps of galactic gas clouds. These estimates are then subtracted from the data. However, because of limited observation of the gas clouds and the complex interactions between the high-energetic protons with the gas, systematic effects remain that may hide point sources in regions of strong diffuse emission.

A new approach to distinguish the signals of such hidden point sources could detect currently undetected sources in the same data. Varying the threshold, we can in principle separate the detection of point sources and diffuse emission. Moreover, our test needs no a-priori assumptions about the complex shape of the gas clouds, but nevertheless the test statistic includes geometric information of the sources in the field of view.

Here we have only applied our method as a proof of principle for a rigorous morphometric null-hypothesis test in gamma-ray astronomy. With further optimizations for applications in astroparticle physics, our approach could have the potential to detect new gamma-ray sources and help to unravel some unknown phenomena.

10 Further Comments and Conclusions

Our new tests are presented for 2-dimensional data sets due to the look-up Table 1 for Minkowski functionals. Nevertheless the table can straightforwardly be generalized to Minkowski functionals in higher dimensions in the following way. In dğ‘‘d-dimensional Euclidean space (d>2ğ‘‘2d>2), the (2Ã—2)22(2\times 2)-neighborhood must be extended to a 2dsuperscript2ğ‘‘2^{d}-neighborhood. The total number of local configurations is therefore 22dsuperscript2superscript2ğ‘‘2^{2^{d}}. For each configuration, the corresponding entry in the look-up table of a Minkowski functional is given by an explicit limit of integrals. Starting with the Minkowski sum of the black pixels with a ball of radius Îµğœ€\varepsilon, that is, the parallel body of the interior, an intersection with the interior of the 2dsuperscript2ğ‘‘2^{d}-neighborhood yields a smooth body for which the integral representation of the Minkowski functionals can be calculated, see SchrÃ¶der-Turk etÂ al., (2011). The limit Îµâ†’0â†’ğœ€0\varepsilon\rightarrow 0 yields the entry in the look-up table. For the volume, this is equal to the number of black pixels divided by 2dsuperscript2ğ‘‘2^{d}, and the contribution to the surface area is given by the number of neighboring pairs of black and white pixels, divided by 2dâˆ’1superscript2ğ‘‘12^{d-1}. The mean width is determined by the opening angles of the edges of black pixels that are neighbors of white pixels. Similarly the local contributions to the Euler characteristic can be expressed by the corners between black and white pixels.

Furthermore, our analysis can also be applied to real data that are distorted by detector effects, like a varying camera acceptance. Instead of an initially homogeneous Poisson point process, the recorded data then follows an inhomogeneous Poisson point process with a known intensity function. Such detector effects can easily be corrected by adding Monte Carlo Poisson events or by performing a Monte Carlo post-selectionÂ GÃ¶ring, (2012); GÃ¶ring etÂ al., (2013). Under the null-hypothesis for the initial data, the resulting post-processed data is again a stationary Poisson point process. If the corrections are applied locally, we can compensate even a strong suppression of signals or subtract strong known point sourcesÂ Klatt, (2016).

We want to indicate some open problems related to the tests. Throughout the article, we assume that the intensity Î»ğœ†\lambda of ğ’«Î»subscriptğ’«ğœ†{\cal P}_{\lambda} is known, so an interesting question is what effect an estimator Î»^^ğœ†\widehat{\lambda} has in the theoretical derivations of the tests. Section 7 describes the behaviour of the Minkowski functionals under fixed alternatives, but it is still unknown the results will lead to statements regarding consistency of the tests aigainst the inhomogeneous Poisson point process and is totally open for point process alternatives with inherent dependency structure. The simulation study suggests that finding a best (data dependent) choice of the parameters cğ‘c and mğ‘šm is crucial to increase the power of the tests. The presented tests contain very nice features, like very fast computation time (even for big data) and flexibility with regard to the choice of parameters, which can lead to better power performance for special alternatives.

Finally, we emphasize that the approach to analyze point patterns by means of Minkowski functionals of binary images might be the starting point of an rich and interesting path to follow for further research, and therefore give some examples.

  • â€¢

    Simulations show that one may obtain better performing procedures by looking at more than one threshold parameter cğ‘c. We suggest to investigate maxcâˆˆâ„•â¡Tcsubscriptğ‘â„•subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\max_{c\in\mathbb{N}}T_{c} or âˆ‘c=1âˆTcsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\sum_{c=1}^{\infty}T_{c} for which we expect procedures with distinctly higher power and a greater flexibility in detecting point-like or extended sources, for first simulations see Klatt, (2016).

  • â€¢

    To detect a local deviation of CSR, we suggest to use the presented tests in a moving window approach, see Lloyd, (2007).

  • â€¢

    In view of Hadwigerâ€™s characterization theorem one might find a linear combination of the Minkowski functionals that is most powerful against alternatives which are additive, continuous and invariant under rigid motions.

  • â€¢

    Tensorial Minkowski functionals are generalizations of Minkowski functionals (also called scalar Minkowski functionals), see Schneider and Weil, (2008); SchrÃ¶der-Turk etÂ al., (2011). They directly quantify the degree of anisotropy and the preferred orientation in an anisotropic system. One can easily derive a corresponding look-up table Klatt, (2016) and define analogous tests to better detect anisotropic deviations from a Poisson point process.

  • â€¢

    The formulae given in Theorem 4.1 and 6.1 can also be used to analyze the non-occurrence of dependency in binary image (or boolean matrix) data directly by means of Minkowski functionals.
